com.riskybusiness.neural

Class Neuron

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.riskybusiness.neural.Neuron
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Neuron>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SigmoidNeuron, StepNeuron

    public abstract class Neuron
extends Object
implements Serializable, Comparable<Neuron>

        This class represents a single artificial cell in a network of said cells that recieves input, processes those inputs, and generates an output. This model was described by Warren S. McCulloch and Walter Pitts in 1943, and is now prevalent in the form of a Perceptron. It is this model that is implemented here, meant for the purpose of playing a RISK game.

        However, this class could be used for other purposes. The implementation for training is called backpropogation, and is used by many neural networks. This is not standard to NEAT, the algorithm implemented to play RISK. This implementation was left in as a tribute to allow other types of non-NEAT neural networks to play RISK as well. In NEAT, however, a Neuron is described by a NeuronGene, and is formed in the genome by the NeuronGene.

        Of course, a perceptron is described by certain characteristics that allows it to be a perceptron. These characteristics include weights for each synapse comming into the Neuron. This is described in the weights object. For traditional training, the Neuron implements a learningRate float that will allow the Neuron to be trained at different speeds. This class is abstract because there are many different activation functions possible for the Neuron. This functionality was left out for future classes to implement.

        Each Neuron allows for two methods of input and output. The first allows for the Neuron to send input statically; that is to say, input is sent into the Neuron all at once. This is implemented in the method fire(float[]). The second allows for sending input dynamically. The input is saved to the Neuron until the Neuron can fire. These two methods allow the Neuron to act as a stand alone entity as well as a functional part of a neural network.

    Since:
    1.6
    See Also:
    Serializable, Comparable, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • inputs

        protected float[] inputs

        The inputs that are saved for the Neuron until it can fire. All inputs in this implementation must be positive.

      • weights

        protected float[] weights

        The weights for each input of the Neuron. These weights line up according to the order in which the inputs were received.

      • learningRate

        protected float learningRate

        The rate at which the weights are adjusted while in the training phase.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Neuron

        public Neuron(float learningRate,
              float... weights)

        Constructs a Neuron which uses the learning rate and weights given as starting points.

        Parameters:
        learningRate - The learning rate to adjust the weights by.
        weights - The initial weights for each input.

      • Neuron

        public Neuron(float... weights)

        Constructs a Neuron which uses the weights given and a learning rate of 1.0.

        Parameters:
        weights - The initial weights for each input.
        See Also:
        Neuron(float[])

      • Neuron

        public Neuron(float learningRate,
              int inputNum)

        Constructs a Neuron which uses the learning rate given and starts the Neuron with the given amount of inputs, not including the bias weights. The weights will start off with a random value between 0 and 1 per input.

        Parameters:
        learningRate - The learning rate to adjust the weights by.
        inputNum - The amount of inputs this neuron will recieve.

      • Neuron

        public Neuron(int inputNum)

        Makes a Neuron with the given number of inputs and a learning rate of 1.0. Also randomizes weights; see link below.

        Parameters:
        inputNum - The amount of inputs this neuron will recieve.
        See Also:
        Neuron(float, int)

    • Method Detail

      • clearInputs

        public void clearInputs()

        Clears the inputs that are stored in this Neuron. This is accomplished by making all of the values in the inputs list -1.

        See Also:
        inputs

      • canFire

        public boolean canFire()

        Determines whether or not this Neuron has the necessary inputs to make an accurate calculation. In other words, this method looks and determines whether or not the inputs list is full.

        Returns:
        true if the input list is full, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        inputs

      • addToInput

        public void addToInput(int index,
                       float output)
                throws ExceededNeuronInputException,
                       InvalidNeuronInputException

        Adds a given output (presumably from another Neuron) to the inputs list.

        Parameters:
        index - The spot to add the output to.
        output - The float to add to the input list.
        Throws:
        ExceededNeuronInputException - When the amount of inputs has already been met.
        InvalidNeuronInputException - When the index has already been populated.
        See Also:
        inputs

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Neuron other)

        Compared the output of this Neuron to that of another. What is returned is the difference between their outputs. If the output of this Neuron was greater, this method will return a positive number, while the inverse is true if the output is lower. NOTE: this only compares their outputs, nothing about the amount of inputs or weight values are checked. Also, one thing to remember is that the integer returned is a rounded version of the output difference: two Neurons could be "equal" but output two completely differnt floats.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<Neuron>
        Parameters:
        other - The other object to compare to.
        Returns:
        A positive number if the output of this Neuron was greater, 0 if they were equal, and -1 if the other output was greater.
        See Also:
        Comparable.compareTo(Object)

      • sum

        protected float sum(float... inputs)
             throws InvalidNeuronInputException

        Sums the list of inputs given.

        Parameters:
        inputs - The list of inputs to be summed.
        Returns:
        The sum of the inputs.
        Throws:
        InvalidNeuronInputException - When the amount of inputs given is not equal to the amount of weights minus one (for the bias weight), this Exception is thrown.
        See Also:
        InvalidNeuronInputException

      • activate

        public abstract float activate(float summation)

        Describes how the Neuron should activate. This could be a step function, or a sigmoid function, or any other function conceivably effective.

        Parameters:
        summation - The sum of the inputs of the Neuron, which tells the Neuron whether to fire or not.
        Returns:
        A float that can be anything one could imagine, as long as the Neuron can make sense of it in the end.

      • fire

        public float fire(float... inputs)

        Actually fires a value based on the inputs. This is done by calling the classes sum(float[]) method on the inputs given, and determining whether or not to fire based on this classes activate(float) method.

        Parameters:
        inputs - The inputs that determine whether or not to fire.
        Returns:
        A float value found by the activation function on the inputs given.
        See Also:
        sum(float[]), activate(float)

      • fire

        public float fire()

        Actually fires a value based on the inputs saved in the Neuron. This is accomplished in the same fashion as if the inputs were sent in staticlly.

        Returns:
        A float value found by the activation function on the inputs that were already dynamically entered.
        See Also:
        fire(float[])

      • getWeights

        public float[] getWeights()

        Returns the weights associated with this Neuron.

        Returns:
        The list containing all of the weights.
        See Also:
        weights

      • adjustWeights

        public void adjustWeights(float... adjustments)
                   throws InvalidNeuronInputException

        Adjusts the weights given the learning rate and weights of this Neuron as well as the adjustments needed for every weight. This error can be calculated as
        ERROR = DESIRED - NEURONOUTPUT
        and is multiplied by the inputs that gave the NEURONOUTPUT. This is done in the {com.riskybusiness.neural.Neuron#train(float, float[]} method, consiquentally calling this method after doing this calculation.

        Parameters:
        adjustments - The list of adjustments to be made, where every position on the list has a corresponding value in the weights list.
        Throws:
        InvalidNeuronInputException - If the amount of adjustments to be made is not equal to the amount of weights found in this Neuron, including the bias weight.
        See Also:
        train(float, float[])

      • setLearningRate

        public void setLearningRate(float learningRate)

        Sets the learning rate for this Neuron.

        Parameters:
        learningRate - The new learning rate.

      • train

        public void train(float desired,
                  float... inputs)
           throws InvalidNeuronInputException

        Trains the Neuron in the traditional sense. See adjustWeights(float[]) for more details.

        Parameters:
        desired - The desired output for the Neuron.
        inputs - The inputs to the Neuron.
        Throws:
        InvalidNeuronInputException - See adjustWeights(float[])

        public void train(float desired)

        Parameters:

        See Also:
